headline: Florida Supreme Court locks in DeSantis-backed redistricting map
sentences: Circuit Judge J. Layne Smith concluded the map proposed by DeSantis was likely unconstitutional because it violated the states Fair Districts standards because it diminished the clout of Black voters by redistributing them from Lawsons seat into four districts.

In its one-page decision, the Supreme Court contended it lacked jurisdiction over the current redistricting lawsuit and that it would be speculative to suggest whether the First Districts eventual decision will provide an appropriate basis for review.

It also freezes in place for now a new congressional map for the nations third-largest state that will likely give Republicans a potential 20-8 advantage in a state where the GOP has only a slight voter registration advantage.

The high courts ruling comes just two weeks before candidates must qualify for this years elections, meaning that the legal challenge wont be resolved in time for a different map to be in place for the 2022 elections.

With todays ruling, the Florida Supreme Court has shown complete disregard for the Florida Constitution and the solemn oath they swore, said Jasmine Burney-Clark, founder of Equal Ground, in a statement.
The Legislature was moving along relatively smoothly until DeSantis  setting aside the normal protocol under past governors  came up with his own maps and submitted them to legislators in January.
Charlie Crist, dissented and contended the Supreme Court would eventually take up the case since it revolves around whether the new map violates anti-gerrymandering provisions adopted by voters.
DeSantis ultimately vetoed the initial map sent to him by legislators who then opted to adopt a proposal entirely drawn by the governors office during an April special session.
Ron DeSantis vetoed the initial map sent to him by legislators who then opted to adopt a proposal drawn by the governors office during an April special session.
Ron DeSantis push to redraw the states congressional map and give a substantial advantage to Republicans will likely remain in place for this years elections.
The state Supreme Court  in a 4-1 divided ruling in which two justices recused themselves  declined to wade into an ongoing legal dispute over the map.
The governor contended that any map that preserved Lawsons seat ran afoul of recent Supreme Court decision because it was a race-based gerrymandering.
DeSantis proposed map is a blatantly unconstitutional attack on Black representation in Florida and a violation of the Fair Districts Amendment.
Florida gained one congressional seat in 2022 due to population growth, for a total of 28, during the once-in-a-decade redistricting process.
They argue the redistricting maps violate Floridas Fair Districts provisions, or anti-gerrymandering amendments in the state constitution.
Smith tried to impose a map that kept Lawsons district intact, but that decision was upended by the 1st District Court of Appeal in May.
Passage of the new maps sparked the coalition of civil and voting rights groups to sue in state court to stop it from going forward.
Two justices  Chief Justice Charles Canady and Alan Lawson  did not participate in the decision but did not explain their recusal.
Voting and civil rights groups opposed to the GOP-approved redistricting map asked the state high court to block it in late May.
Groups that challenged the map sharply criticized Thursdays ruling and said they will not drop their underlying lawsuit.
This new map also dismantles the North Florida congressional seat held by Rep. Al Lawson, a Black Democrat.

| Marta Lavandier, File/AP Photo
By Gary Fineout
 06/02/2022 02:59 PM EDT
TALLAHASSEE, Fla.  Florida Gov.
The state Supreme Courts decision means an appeals court will decide the current legal challenge.
This is another big blow to Democrats hopes of holding onto their majority in the U.S. House.
The decision was endorsed by four justices  including three who were appointed by DeSantis.
We, the people of Florida, are not going anywhere, and the fight is not over.
Justice Jorge Labarga, who was appointed to the court by former Gov.
Justice Lawson is not related to Rep. Al Lawson.
Floridas primary will be held on Aug. 23.
